Motion.title: Motion
Motion.summary: Motion describes the change in position of an object with respect to time and reference point.
keyPoints: Motion is relative and depends on the observer's frame of reference
Distance is the total path covered, while displacement is the shortest distance between initial and final positions
Speed is distance/time, velocity is displacement/time (vector quantity)
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity
Equations of motion: v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², v² = u² + 2as
formulas: Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time

Force and Laws of Motion.title: Force and Laws of Motion
Force and Laws of Motion.summary: Newton's laws of motion describe the relationship between forces acting on a body and its motion.
keyPoints: First Law (Inertia): An object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by external force
Second Law: F = ma (Force equals mass times acceleration)
Third Law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction
Momentum (p) = mass × velocity
Conservation of momentum in isolated systems
formulas: Impulse = Change in Momentum = F × t

Gravitation.title: Gravitation
Gravitation.summary: Universal law of gravitation explains the force of attraction between any two masses in the universe.
keyPoints: Every object attracts every other object with a force proportional to product of their masses
Force is inversely proportional to square of distance between centers
Gravitational constant G = 6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ Nm²/kg²
Acceleration due to gravity on Earth's surface g = 9.8 m/s²
Weight = mass × acceleration due to gravity

Work and Energy.title: Work and Energy
Work and Energy.summary: Work is done when force causes displacement. Energy is the capacity to do work.
keyPoints: Work = Force × Displacement × cos(θ)
Kinetic Energy: Energy possessed by moving objects (KE = ½mv²)
Potential Energy: Energy possessed due to position (PE = mgh)
Law of conservation of energy: Energy can neither be created nor destroyed
Power is the rate of doing work (P = W/t)

Sound.title: Sound
Sound.summary: Sound is a mechanical wave that propagates through a medium by vibrations.
keyPoints: Sound requires a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel
Longitudinal wave with compressions and rarefactions
Speed of sound in air at 25°C ≈ 346 m/s
Frequency determines pitch, amplitude determines loudness
Reflection of sound causes echo (minimum distance 17.2m for distinct echo)
formulas: Range of human hearing: 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz

Light - Reflection and Refraction.title: Light - Reflection and Refraction
Light - Reflection and Refraction.summary: Light travels in straight lines and exhibits reflection and refraction when interacting with surfaces.
keyPoints: Law of reflection: Angle of incidence = Angle of reflection
Refraction is bending of light when passing from one medium to another
Refractive index: ratio of speed of light in vacuum to speed in medium
Snell's law: n₁sin(i) = n₂sin(r)
Lens formula: 1/f = 1/v - 1/u; Magnification: m = v/u
formulas: Refractive Index (n) = Speed of light in vacuum / Speed in medium

The Human Eye and the Colourful World.title: The Human Eye and the Colourful World
The Human Eye and the Colourful World.summary: The human eye is a natural optical instrument that enables us to see the colorful world around us.
keyPoints: Cornea, pupil, lens, and retina are key parts of the eye
Power of accommodation: ability to focus on near and far objects
Near point (25 cm) and far point (infinity) define vision range
Myopia (short-sightedness) corrected with concave lens
Hypermetropia (long-sightedness) corrected with convex lens
Dispersion of white light through prism produces spectrum (VIBGYOR)
formulas: Power of lens (P) = 1/f (in meters), measured in Dioptre (D)
Angular magnification of simple microscope = D/f

Electricity.title: Electricity
Electricity.summary: Electric current is the flow of electric charge through a conductor.
keyPoints: Electric current: flow of electrons, measured in Amperes (A)
Potential difference: work done to move unit charge, measured in Volts (V)
Ohm's Law: V = IR (at constant temperature)
Resistance depends on length, area, and resistivity of material
Series: R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃; Parallel: 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + 1/R₃
Electric power: P = VI = I²R = V²/R
Electric energy: E = P × t

Magnetic Effects of Electric Current.title: Magnetic Effects of Electric Current
Magnetic Effects of Electric Current.summary: A current-carrying conductor produces a magnetic field around it.
keyPoints: Right-hand thumb rule determines direction of magnetic field
Magnetic field due to straight conductor is circular
Solenoid: coil with magnetic field similar to bar magnet
Electromagnet: temporary magnet created by electric current
Fleming's left-hand rule: Force on current-carrying conductor in magnetic field
Electromagnetic induction: changing magnetic field induces current
formulas: Force on conductor: F = BIL sin(θ)
Magnetic field at center of circular coil: B = μ₀NI/2r

Sources of Energy.title: Sources of Energy
Sources of Energy.summary: Energy sources are classified as renewable and non-renewable based on their availability.
keyPoints: Renewable: Solar, wind, hydro, biomass, geothermal, tidal
Non-renewable: Fossil fuels (coal, petroleum, natural gas), nuclear
Good energy source: high energy output, easy availability, economical
Fossil fuels cause pollution and are being depleted
Solar energy is clean and abundant but requires large area
Nuclear energy is highly efficient but produces radioactive waste

Matter in Our Surroundings.title: Matter in Our Surroundings
Matter in Our Surroundings.summary: Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space. It exists in three states: solid, liquid, and gas.
keyPoints: Solids have definite shape and volume, strong intermolecular forces
Liquids have definite volume but no definite shape
Gases have neither definite shape nor volume
Change of state involves absorption or release of energy
Evaporation causes cooling effect
Sublimation: direct conversion from solid to gas (e.g., dry ice, camphor)

Is Matter Around Us Pure?.title: Is Matter Around Us Pure?
Is Matter Around Us Pure?.summary: Pure substances have fixed composition, while mixtures contain two or more substances.
keyPoints: Pure substances: elements (single type of atom) and compounds (fixed ratio of atoms)
Mixtures: homogeneous (uniform composition) and heterogeneous (non-uniform)
Solutions: homogeneous mixtures (solute + solvent)
Separation techniques: filtration, evaporation, distillation, chromatography
Concentration: mass/volume percentage, mass/mass percentage
Tyndall effect: scattering of light by colloidal particles
formulas: Mass percentage = (Mass of solute / Mass of solution) × 100

Atoms and Molecules.title: Atoms and Molecules
Atoms and Molecules.summary: Atoms are the smallest particles of elements, and molecules are combinations of atoms.
keyPoints: Law of conservation of mass: mass is neither created nor destroyed
Law of constant proportions: compound always has same elements in fixed ratio
Atomic mass unit (amu): 1/12th the mass of carbon-12 atom
Molecular mass: sum of atomic masses of all atoms in molecule
Mole: 6.022 × 10²³ particles (Avogadro's number)
Molar mass: mass of one mole of substance
formulas: Number of moles = Given mass / Molar mass
Number of particles = Number of moles × Avogadro's number

Structure of the Atom.title: Structure of the Atom
Structure of the Atom.summary: Atoms consist of a nucleus containing protons and neutrons, surrounded by electrons.
keyPoints: Protons: positive charge, mass ≈ 1 amu, in nucleus
Neutrons: no charge, mass ≈ 1 amu, in nucleus
Electrons: negative charge, negligible mass, in shells around nucleus
Atomic number (Z): number of protons in nucleus
Mass number (A): sum of protons and neutrons
Isotopes: same atomic number, different mass numbers
Electronic configuration: K(2), L(8), M(18), N(32) shells
Valency: combining capacity of atom

Chemical Reactions and Equations.title: Chemical Reactions and Equations
Chemical Reactions and Equations.summary: Chemical reactions involve breaking and forming of bonds, represented by balanced equations.
keyPoints: Combination: A + B → AB
Decomposition: AB → A + B
Displacement: A + BC → AC + B
Double displacement: AB + CD → AD + CB
Oxidation: gain of oxygen or loss of hydrogen/electrons
Reduction: loss of oxygen or gain of hydrogen/electrons
Exothermic: releases heat (combustion); Endothermic: absorbs heat (photosynthesis)

Acids, Bases and Salts.title: Acids, Bases and Salts
Acids, Bases and Salts.summary: Acids are sour and turn blue litmus red, bases are bitter and turn red litmus blue.
keyPoints: Acids: release H⁺ ions in water (HCl, H₂SO₄, HNO₃)
Bases: release OH⁻ ions in water (NaOH, KOH, Ca(OH)₂)
pH scale: 0-14, <7 acidic, 7 neutral, >7 basic
Indicators: litmus, phenolphthalein, methyl orange
Neutralization: Acid + Base → Salt + Water
Common salt (NaCl), washing soda (Na₂CO₃), baking soda (NaHCO₃)
Water of crystallization: fixed number of water molecules in crystal

Metals and Non-Metals.title: Metals and Non-Metals
Metals and Non-Metals.summary: Elements are classified as metals and non-metals based on their physical and chemical properties.
keyPoints: Metals: lustrous, malleable, ductile, good conductors, form positive ions
Non-metals: brittle, poor conductors, form negative ions
Reactivity series: K > Na > Ca > Mg > Al > Zn > Fe > Pb > H > Cu > Ag > Au
More reactive metal displaces less reactive metal from its compound
Metals react with oxygen to form oxides (mostly basic)
Metals react with water to form hydroxides and hydrogen
Metals react with acids to form salts and hydrogen
Extraction: roasting, calcination, reduction, refining

Carbon and its Compounds.title: Carbon and its Compounds
Carbon and its Compounds.summary: Carbon forms millions of compounds due to its unique property of catenation.
keyPoints: Catenation: self-linking property of carbon atoms
Tetravalency: carbon has valency of 4
Hydrocarbons: compounds of carbon and hydrogen (alkanes, alkenes, alkynes)
Functional groups: -OH (alcohol), -COOH (carboxylic acid), -CHO (aldehyde), -CO- (ketone)
Isomerism: same molecular formula, different structures
Homologous series: same functional group, differ by -CH₂-
Combustion: complete (CO₂ + H₂O), incomplete (CO + H₂O)
Ethanol and ethanoic acid are important carbon compounds

Periodic Classification of Elements.title: Periodic Classification of Elements
Periodic Classification of Elements.summary: Modern periodic table arranges elements in increasing order of atomic numbers.
keyPoints: Periods: horizontal rows (1 to 7)
Groups: vertical columns (1 to 18)
Atomic size decreases across period, increases down group
Metallic character decreases across period, increases down group
Valency first increases then decreases across period
Elements in same group have similar properties
Noble gases (Group 18) are inert with complete outer shells

The Fundamental Unit of Life.title: The Fundamental Unit of Life
The Fundamental Unit of Life.summary: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.
keyPoints: Cell theory: All living organisms are made of cells
Prokaryotic: no membrane-bound nucleus (bacteria)
Eukaryotic: membrane-bound nucleus (plants, animals, fungi)
Plasma membrane: selectively permeable, controls entry/exit
Cell wall: rigid outer layer in plants, provides shape
Nucleus: contains DNA, controls cell activities
Mitochondria: powerhouse of cell, produces ATP
Chloroplasts: site of photosynthesis in plant cells
Endoplasmic reticulum: protein and lipid synthesis
Golgi apparatus: packaging and dispatching of materials

Tissues.title: Tissues
Tissues.summary: A tissue is a group of cells similar in structure and function working together.
keyPoints: Plant tissues: Meristematic (dividing) and Permanent (non-dividing)
Simple permanent: Parenchyma, Collenchyma, Sclerenchyma
Complex permanent: Xylem (water transport), Phloem (food transport)
Animal tissues: Epithelial, Connective, Muscular, Nervous
Epithelial: protective covering, simple and compound types
Connective: connects tissues, includes blood, bone, cartilage
Muscular: movement, types - skeletal, smooth, cardiac
Nervous: transmits electrical impulses, consists of neurons

Diversity in Living Organisms.title: Diversity in Living Organisms
Diversity in Living Organisms.summary: Classification groups organisms based on similarities and differences in their characteristics.
keyPoints: Hierarchy: Kingdom > Phylum > Class > Order > Family > Genus > Species
Five kingdoms: Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia
Monera: prokaryotic, unicellular (bacteria)
Protista: eukaryotic, unicellular (amoeba, paramecium)
Fungi: heterotrophic, decomposers (mushroom, yeast)
Plantae: autotrophic, have chlorophyll
Animalia: heterotrophic, multicellular
Vertebrates: have backbone (fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals)
Invertebrates: no backbone (arthropods, molluscs, worms)

Life Processes.title: Life Processes
Life Processes.summary: Life processes are the basic functions performed by living organisms to maintain life.
keyPoints: Nutrition: autotrophic (photosynthesis) and heterotrophic
Photosynthesis: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ (in presence of sunlight and chlorophyll)
Respiration: aerobic (with O₂) and anaerobic (without O₂)
Transportation: in plants (xylem, phloem), in animals (blood vessels)
Excretion: removal of waste products
Human excretory system: kidneys, ureters, urinary bladder, urethra
Nephron: functional unit of kidney

Control and Coordination.title: Control and Coordination
Control and Coordination.summary: Control and coordination in organisms occur through nervous system and hormonal system.
keyPoints: Nervous system: rapid control through electrical impulses
Neuron: structural and functional unit of nervous system
Reflex action: quick automatic response to stimulus
Central nervous system: brain and spinal cord
Peripheral nervous system: nerves connecting CNS to body parts
Endocrine system: slow control through chemical messengers (hormones)
Major glands: pituitary, thyroid, adrenal, pancreas, gonads
Plant hormones: auxin (growth), gibberellin (stem elongation), cytokinin (cell division)
Tropic movements: phototropism, geotropism, hydrotropism

How do Organisms Reproduce?.title: How do Organisms Reproduce?
How do Organisms Reproduce?.summary: Reproduction is the biological process by which organisms produce offspring.
keyPoints: Asexual reproduction: single parent, no gamete fusion (fission, budding, fragmentation, spore formation, vegetative propagation)
Sexual reproduction: two parents, fusion of gametes
Flower parts: sepals, petals, stamens (male), carpel (female)
Pollination: transfer of pollen from anther to stigma (self/cross)
Fertilization: fusion of male and female gametes
Human reproductive system: male (testes, vas deferens) and female (ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus)
Menstruation: monthly cycle in females (28 days)
Contraception methods: barrier, chemical, surgical

Heredity and Evolution.title: Heredity and Evolution
Heredity and Evolution.summary: Heredity is the transmission of characteristics from parents to offspring through genes.
keyPoints: Gene: unit of heredity, segment of DNA
Chromosome: thread-like structure carrying genes
Mendel's laws: Law of dominance, Law of segregation, Law of independent assortment
Monohybrid cross: single trait inheritance (3:1 ratio in F₂)
Dihybrid cross: two traits inheritance (9:3:3:1 ratio in F₂)
Sex determination: XX (female), XY (male) in humans
Evolution: gradual change in species over time
Natural selection: survival of the fittest
Evidence: fossils, homologous organs, analogous organs, vestigial organs

Our Environment.title: Our Environment
Our Environment.summary: The environment includes all living and non-living components that surround us.
keyPoints: Ecosystem: interaction between living organisms and physical environment
Food chain: linear sequence of organisms feeding on each other
Food web: interconnected food chains
Trophic levels: producers (plants) → primary consumers → secondary consumers → tertiary consumers
10% law: only 10% energy transfers to next trophic level
Biodegradable: can be broken down by microorganisms (paper, food waste)
Non-biodegradable: cannot be broken down (plastics, metals)
Ozone layer: protects from harmful UV rays, depleted by CFCs

Management of Natural Resources.title: Management of Natural Resources
Management of Natural Resources.summary: Sustainable management ensures resources are available for future generations.
keyPoints: Three R's: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
Forest conservation: prevents soil erosion, maintains water cycle, biodiversity
Wildlife conservation: protecting endangered species and habitats
Water harvesting: rainwater collection for future use
Coal and petroleum: fossil fuels, non-renewable resources
Reduce dependency on fossil fuels through renewable energy
Sustainable development: meeting present needs without compromising future

Number Systems.title: Number Systems
Number Systems.summary: Number systems include natural, whole, integers, rational, and irrational numbers.
keyPoints: Natural numbers (N): 1, 2, 3, 4, ...
Whole numbers (W): 0, 1, 2, 3, ...
Rational numbers (Q): p/q form where q ≠ 0
Irrational numbers: cannot be expressed as p/q (√2, π, e)
Real numbers (R): all rational and irrational numbers
Properties: closure, commutative, associative, distributive
Decimal expansion: terminating or non-terminating repeating (rational), non-terminating non-repeating (irrational)

Polynomials.title: Polynomials
Polynomials.summary: A polynomial is an algebraic expression with variables and coefficients involving only addition, subtraction, and multiplication.
keyPoints: Degree: highest power of variable
Linear polynomial: ax + b (degree 1)
Quadratic polynomial: ax² + bx + c (degree 2)
Cubic polynomial: ax³ + bx² + cx + d (degree 3)
Zeroes: values of x for which p(x) = 0
Factor theorem: if p(a) = 0, then (x - a) is a factor
Remainder theorem: when p(x) is divided by (x - a), remainder is p(a)

Coordinate Geometry.title: Coordinate Geometry
Coordinate Geometry.summary: Coordinate geometry uses algebraic methods to study geometric properties using coordinates.
keyPoints: Cartesian plane: X-axis (horizontal) and Y-axis (vertical)
Point: (x, y) where x is abscissa, y is ordinate
Origin: (0, 0)
Quadrants: I (+, +), II (-, +), III (-, -), IV (+, -)
Distance formula: finds distance between two points
Section formula: finds coordinates of point dividing line segment
Midpoint formula: finds midpoint of line segment
formulas: Section formula: ((mx₂ + nx₁)/(m + n), (my₂ + ny₁)/(m + n))

Linear Equations in Two Variables.title: Linear Equations in Two Variables
Linear Equations in Two Variables.summary: A linear equation in two variables represents a straight line on the coordinate plane.
keyPoints: Standard form: ax + by + c = 0
Every solution (x, y) is a point on the line
Graph is always a straight line
Two lines can be parallel, intersecting, or coincident
Parallel lines: a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ ≠ c₁/c₂ (no solution)
Intersecting lines: a₁/a₂ ≠ b₁/b₂ (unique solution)
Coincident lines: a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ = c₁/c₂ (infinite solutions)

Triangles.title: Triangles
Triangles.summary: Similar triangles have the same shape but different sizes with proportional sides.
keyPoints: Congruent triangles: same size and shape (SSS, SAS, ASA, RHS)
Similar triangles: same shape, proportional sides (AAA, SSS, SAS)
Pythagoras theorem: In right triangle, h² = b² + p²
Basic proportionality theorem (Thales): If line parallel to one side divides other two sides proportionally
Areas of similar triangles are proportional to squares of corresponding sides
Angle bisector theorem divides opposite side in ratio of adjacent sides

Quadrilaterals.title: Quadrilaterals
Quadrilaterals.summary: A quadrilateral is a polygon with four sides, four vertices, and four angles.
keyPoints: Sum of all angles = 360°
Parallelogram: opposite sides parallel and equal, opposite angles equal, diagonals bisect each other
Rectangle: parallelogram with all angles 90°, diagonals equal
Rhombus: parallelogram with all sides equal, diagonals perpendicular
Square: rectangle with all sides equal, all properties of rectangle and rhombus
Trapezium: one pair of opposite sides parallel
Kite: two pairs of adjacent sides equal, diagonals perpendicular
formulas: Area of trapezium = (1/2) × (sum of parallel sides) × height

Areas of Parallelograms and Triangles.title: Areas of Parallelograms and Triangles
Areas of Parallelograms and Triangles.summary: Figures on the same base and between same parallels have specific area relationships.
keyPoints: Parallelograms on same base and between same parallels have equal areas
Triangles on same base and between same parallels have equal areas
Triangle is half the area of parallelogram on same base and between same parallels
Median divides triangle into two triangles of equal area
Area of trapezium = (1/2) × (sum of parallel sides) × distance between them

Circles.title: Circles
Circles.summary: A circle is the locus of all points equidistant from a fixed point called the center.
keyPoints: Chord: line segment joining two points on circle
Diameter: longest chord passing through center
Tangent: line touching circle at exactly one point
Secant: line intersecting circle at two points
Perpendicular from center bisects the chord
Equal chords are equidistant from center
Angle subtended by arc at center is double the angle at circumference
Angles in same segment are equal
Angle in semicircle is 90°

Constructions.title: Constructions
Constructions.summary: Geometric constructions using compass and ruler to create precise figures.
keyPoints: Division of line segment in given ratio
Construction of tangents to circle from external point
Construction of triangle similar to given triangle with given scale factor
Bisecting an angle using compass
Perpendicular bisector of line segment
Constructing angles: 60°, 90°, 120°, 30°, 45°

Heron's Formula.title: Heron's Formula
Heron's Formula.summary: Heron's formula calculates the area of a triangle when all three sides are known.
keyPoints: Used when three sides are known but height is not given
First calculate semi-perimeter (s)
Then apply Heron's formula
Can be extended to quadrilaterals by dividing into triangles
Particularly useful for scalene triangles

Surface Areas and Volumes.title: Surface Areas and Volumes
Surface Areas and Volumes.summary: Study of 3D shapes including their surface areas and volumes.
keyPoints: Cuboid: 6 rectangular faces
Cube: all faces are squares
Cylinder: circular base and top
Cone: circular base with apex
Sphere: all points equidistant from center
Hemisphere: half of sphere
Combination of solids: add or subtract volumes
formulas: Cuboid: TSA = 2(lb + bh + hl), Volume = l × b × h
Cylinder: CSA = 2πrh, TSA = 2πr(r + h), Volume = πr²h
Cone: CSA = πrl, TSA = πr(l + r), Volume = (1/3)πr²h

Statistics.title: Statistics
Statistics.summary: Statistics deals with collection, organization, analysis, and interpretation of data.
keyPoints: Mean: average of all observations
Median: middle value when arranged in order
Mode: most frequently occurring value
Range: difference between highest and lowest values
Frequency distribution: tabular representation of data
Class interval: grouped data ranges
Cumulative frequency: sum of frequencies up to that class
Graphical representation: histogram, frequency polygon, ogive
formulas: Mean = Sum of observations / Number of observations

Probability.title: Probability
Probability.summary: Probability measures the likelihood of occurrence of an event.
keyPoints: Probability ranges from 0 to 1
Impossible event: P(E) = 0
Certain event: P(E) = 1
Sum of probabilities of all outcomes = 1
Complementary events: P(E) + P(not E) = 1
Experimental probability based on actual experiments
Theoretical probability based on logical reasoning
formulas: P(E) = Number of favorable outcomes / Total number of outcomes
